Pirate, Sunny and Surf. I couldn't agree with you more.Whether or not those in the US wish to acknowledge it, the absence of a consistent and co-ordinated, medically-led, national policy in the US during this pandemic is a significant part of the problem, and not just for the US. It is also a significant contributor to why the current travel issues are so exacerbated for the rest of the world. Normally, political actions have little effect on travel, short of perhaps a closure of borders or introduction of new visa requirements. These are far from normal times. The problem is less about politics and more about an intellectual propensity to regularly disagree with much of the rest of the world, together with a tendency to downplay the issues and pooh-pooh the advice of medical experts. That is not the case in most other locations, including SXM. But it has an impact on all those other countries, including SXM. So for everyone to have to pussy-foot around the issue is in fact part of the problem. No one wants to bell the cat.It has a direct impact on when or if international travel might have a chance to return to something resembling normal anytime soon and whether or not economies might be allowed to flourish. That has a direct impact on when smaller nations like SXM, whose economies rely heavily on tourism, can reopen. It is therefore a "travel" issue, unlike one we have ever before seen. That is why it is a topic on so many fora.Countries like SXM are desperately trying to find a way to balance protecting the lives and safety of both their citizens and visitors, while opening up their country and economy. The fact Covid-19 is still raging through the USA, which is such a huge part of international tourism, also contributes to the complexity of finding that balance and the cost of keeping everyone safe.Please, let's not brush all these considerations and concerns aside, and therefore ignore them, by resorting to dragging out the old name-calling trope of calling them "political". We are better than that!
